episode.title: Simons v. Miami Beach First National Bank

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Number 363, Lucy C. Simons, Petitioner, versus Miami Beach First National Bank.
Mr. Ward.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.

This is a domestic relations case arising out of the question of whether or not the Florida courts are required to give full faith and credit to a New York separation decree in connection with the establishment of a widow's right to dower subsequent to the entry of an ex parte divorce decree in the Florida courts.
As this Court is well aware, there's no tendency for the solution to the problem of the domestic relations problems that arise in the United States.
And I think that each case must be taken and analyzed by reason and logic in order to reach a conclusion that's fair to all of the parties.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Counsel for that, do you mind if I state to you what my problem with your case is?

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: When did you present the federal -- this federal question, this full faith and credit?

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: I think the problem has been presented at all stages of the proceedings, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: I wasn't able to --

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: -- the District Court of Appeals --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: I hope --

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: -- and by the assignments of error.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: And I hope it was presented in the petition for rehearing before the Court of Appeals, but was that the first time?

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: No sir, I think it was presented in the original assignments of error.
It was before the lower court when the --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Well, could you help -- help me find those and -- not this minute I say --

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: -- but during the course of your argument.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: Yes sir.

I think that the problem has arisen originally because the courts, not only the trial court, the District Court of Appeals, and the Supreme Court of Florida have failed to recognize the point that we attempt to assert.
They have in each instance decree that we were barred by reason of the fact that this point was not raised at the time the divorce suit was instituted.

The Florida courts have taken the position that is incumbent upon the nonresident wife to come into the State of Florida and to present this defense of res judicata or requiring the Florida Court to give full faith and credit to the New York separation decree at the time that the husband institutes the divorce proceeding.
And that she cannot wait until a subsequent date to make this presentation.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: My -- my problem is this Mr. Ward, and again, I -- I leave it to you that to answer in the course of your argument if you cannot right now but even if the wife had done that, then the Florida Court would have said, “Alright yes, you know you've told us about this separate -- the separate maintenance decree, and we recognized it and we ordered the husband to keep paying you.”
Well, in fact that's what did happened.
He did pay all his lifetime until his death.
And so, what -- what would have been gained?
What more -- what more could have been gained?

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: Well, what could have been gained, Your Honor, is the rights that have been established by the New York decree that the wife is -- that this woman was to remain the wife of this man and to participate in his estate.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I don't understand that that was what that decree provided.
It provided separate -- a legal separation and separate maintenance alimony.
It didn't -- it didn't say you have to remain married to each other the rest of your lives.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And in New York, this could -- this could have been followed by an absolute divorce, could it not?

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: On -- by the wife or by the husband on separate grounds, not on the grounds that were adjudicated in this particular course of action.
And that is the point that we -- we argue here.
As this Court is well aware, there is advanced distinction between a separate maintenance decree and a divorce decree.
There are rights that remain to the person receiving the benefit of that decree in a separation decree that do not remain after divorce decree.
And the basic and main right is not only the right to support but it's the right to participate in the husband's estate and to assert this dower right.

The inchoate right of dower remains when you grant a separation decree to a wife, she, in the eyes of the law remains the wife of that man but entitled to live separate and apart and upon his death has the right to participate in his estate by way of the inchoate right of dower attaching and become choate.

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: You're arguing that Mr. Simons (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, from the outset Mr. Justice Goldberg, let me explain this.

We do not take the position and I think we cannot on the state of this record that the Florida Court did not in fact have jurisdiction to enter the divorce decree because that is based upon the disputed issue of fact which was resolved against us.
Our position --

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: In other words, the lower court includes the (Inaudible) leaving you the rest of the standard here.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: Is that true?

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: Court of Appeals never decided that.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: Whether (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: In other words, in order for us to reach (Inaudible) it's necessary for us to decide the residence question.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: That's correct, sir.

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: (Inaudible) in the court remain disputed.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: That's right.
We disputed that and lost it.

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: Now, the facts have been adjudicated in here.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: Now, the (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: No sir.
Not insofar as it affects -- it affects marital status.

I might point out at this point that the sole basis of the argument of the petitioner here is based upon this Court's decisions in the Estin versus Estin case and later in this Armstrong case and the Vanderbilt case, the theory of divisible divorce.

We do not contend here that insofar as this man was concerned, Mr. Simon, that Florida did not have a right to affect his marital status insofar as it affected society and affected his rights to -- to remarry or to live with another woman or to this -- that this decree could in anyway illegitimatize, if there is such a word, his children, if he had remarried.
We don't have that case here.

He did not remarried but I -- we do not attack the -- the marital status as established by this Court in distinguishing indivisible divorce, in distinguishing between marital status on one -- one side and on the other side the property rights of the wife.
The point we raise is this, is in New York with both people there, these people were married in New York.
They remained residents of New York.

They had a very hotly contested New York litigation which is shown by the decree in the record, wherein the court in New York found that the husband had been guilty of extreme cruelty towards the wife or cruelty and inhuman treatment.
And that therefore, she was entitled to live separate or apart from him.
And that she was entitled to receive support from him.

Now, inherent in that decree is also the proposition that she was entitled insofar as her property rights were concerned to remain his wife so that she would be entitled upon his death to assert a dower claim if he wrote her out of his will.
Now with --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: It's not the same.
The jurisdiction of the Florida Court entered the divorce proceeding, terminating the marriage.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That nevertheless, he was sufficiently obliged, so that is -- that she would assert a dower.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: Yes sir, she was of that same sufficiently his wife to assert the dower claim as this Court has ruled, she had sufficiently his wife to assert an alimony claim subsequent to an ex parte --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Are you saying that the Court had jurisdiction to grant -- jurisdiction of the case now in Court, and they made a mistake in granting the divorce.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I thought you -- I thought you said they weren't entitled to grant the divorce in that jurisdiction but they made a mistake, namely they didn't -- they -- they shouldn't have granted a divorce on the ground they did.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: No, Mr. -- I'd say this.
That is --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But a while ago, you said a while ago that the Florida Court was not entitled to grant a divorce on the ground that it used because that ground was precluded by the -- by the New York --

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: That is correct, insofar as it affected her marital rights.
That's correct.
Insofar as it affected her --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But you did it insofar that it affected her property rights.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: Property rights, yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You're claiming that they have a right to sever the relationship of husband and wife per se.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But the other statement is to give full faith and credit to any property judgment.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Whether they -- whether they would have to give it to the separation or not.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: I'm saying this, Your Honor, that insofar as Florida is concerned and we're not here concerned with whether New York would have to give full faith and credit to the Florida decree at all, that was not involved.
What I'm saying is this, is that New York has decreed on a -- or these two people had their day in court in New York and -- and the -- the decree was rendered against the husband.
It was found that he was at fault and therefore the wife had the right to live separate and apart from him.
Now, if he subsequently goes to Florida, and under this Court's theory on the Estin cases and in those other cases.
He can go down there and you have said that Florida has the right because he's a domicile.

They have the right to -- to change his marital status, so that in the betterment of society and in the betterment of family relations that his children would be legitimate if he remarried, and that sort of thing, that Florida has the right to do that.
But that that would not affect the wife's or the former wife's rights who lives in another state insofar as alimony or her property rights.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But now what -- I just want to make sure I understand you correctly.
The -- after that far a divorce could be, the husband is free to remarry without being -- being bigamous under United States court.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: I would assume so, yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What you -- what you're saying is that he -- his first wife was still sufficiently his wife that that continued her right to assert dower on his death.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: That property right, yes, the same that she has the property right to assert -- to make him pay alimony.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Because he's not his wife, (Voice Overlap) of -- of fining him if remarry, guilty of any crime, but she is his wife sufficiently have retained whatever property rights you say she's got.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: She has retained her property rights --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How do you let yourself get into that situation, sufficiently his wife --

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: Well, I know --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Does she had to be sufficiently his wife and does she -- might she have the right because of the law whether she's his wife or not his wife.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: I would agree with you, Justice Black.
I don't think it's sufficiently, following Justice Brennan's remarks, I was just answering him but I -- I say this, you got to separate which this Court did by their ruling in Estin v. Estin.
You got to separate it.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Estin was the case where -- is that a court decree if taken literally would have wiped out the prior New York alimony decree.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: And there's no prior New York decree of any kind that would be affected by here or by anything that Florida did.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: Yes sir.
There is the prior New --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: So that Estin was -- is merely an illustration of your point but it isn't quite applicable.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: No sir.
I don't say that it's 100% applicable.
You must start from the theory that there is such thing as divisible divorce which this Court has announced.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But Mr. -- Mr. Ward, certainly, (Inaudible) first year of the lawsuit, that dower is a right that's attached to surviving widows, isn't it?
Now, what you're talking about here is that dower arrangements.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: And what I'm talking about is that --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And when they say sufficiently his, wife I don't think it's -- I don't think it's an act of (Voice Overlap).

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: What I'm -- what I am talking about is that the New York court has decreed in a litigated two-party proceeding where both people who were before the Court, that this woman was entitled to live separate and apart from this man and that he wasn't entitled to live separate and apart from her or to get a divorce from her.
Now, the question is --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But did that touch do -- dower interest, that New York decree?

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: Inherently, yes sir because inherently it is said that she has the right to live separate and apart from him but -- and -- and to receive support from him but she has the right to re -- if nothing else would have happened, if this divorce hadn't been entered, she would have obviously had the right to assert a dower claim against his estate.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But there was nothing in that decree that said, “Neither one of you can ever bring suit for divorce?”

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: No sir, I don't think not --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: There was nothing in there saying, “You have to stay married to each other until the first one of you dies?”

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well that's -- so since there wasn't, then that could have been followed as it was followed by a divorce.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: It could have been if it was based upon different grounds.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, this is what I asked you a while ago.
I thought you answered me it didn't make any difference what the grounds --

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- which is by the lower court.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: No, Justice White.
I don't want to answer that question.
The question is that he tried to and got a divorce in Florida off on grounds that were the same as those that had already been adjudicated in New York and I say he can't do that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So Florida -- the Florida Court should not have granted a divorce on those grounds.
That --

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, that's exactly -- that's absolutely contrary to what you've said a while ago to me.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: No sir.
I don't -- I'm talking about --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, should or should not the Florida Court have granted a divorce from the grounds that it did?

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: I think originally if she would have gone in --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, how about if you answer the question, should it -- should it have granted a divorce from the grounds that it did or not.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Those grounds were not available to the New York or Florida Court.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: They had been adjudicated by the New York separation decree.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well then, there was no divorce.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: If you take it that far, yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: This full faith and credit ground is good.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: It was res jud --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That there was no divorce.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: It was res judicata on the issues presented to the Florida Court.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And the full faith and credit?

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And so there was no divorce?

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is that your point here?

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Does your case depend on this finding with you on that point?

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: Well Your Honor, my case depends upon this Court extending the doctrine of divisible divorce to determine what Florida did was this, they have ruled that this woman cannot later, after this man dies and when this right of dower then becomes choate cannot come in and assert the New York decree.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I understand that.
What I was -- what I was wondering is, does your case depend on the answer you just gave to Justice White namely that this was -- was not a proper divorce?

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: It was not a proper divorce insofar as it affected her property rights in her husband's estate.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But he would still be bigamist when he remarry?

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: If you recognized the doctrine of divisible divorce, no sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well yes, but you're saying that this ground was not available before the Court to use it as -- as a divorce.
That the ground had been adjudicated in New York that he was entitled to use that ground.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And if the Florida Court shouldn't have entered a decree at all.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Would you tell them they shouldn't have entered -- entered a decree?

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That if a counsel have -- did -- did you say to the -- the Florida courts that this ground was unavailable on res judicata in full faith and credit ground?

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: That was what was asserted in this last suit that's before the Court now.
And the Florida Court did not rule that it was a res judicata or did not rule on the fact that whether it was or was not.
They said that it wasn't available.
That this was a defense that this woman had to present at the time the divorce suit was filed, and I say that's wrong.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And so you didn't -- and -- and you didn't commit on that divorce suit at all, did you?

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And which was your -- but you concede there was residence.

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: On the disputed issues, I can -- I don't -- I cannot dispute it.
No sir on the finding of disputed fact as contained in the record.

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: Assuming the court has jurisdiction, it got waiver of full faith and credit ground, could it come to that court and assert your --

turn.speaker: robert_c_ward
turn.label: Mr. Robert C. Ward
turn.text: I don't believe so --

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
